criteria: Description of Physical Setting and Support for Civilization
Accuracy and Use of Geographic Terminology
descriptions: Fails to identify any major river systems of early India.
Identifies only one major river system but with significant inaccuracies or omissions.
Identifies two major river systems but lacks detail or contains minor inaccuracies.
Identifies major river systems (Indus, Ganges, Brahmaputra) but provides limited descriptive information.
Accurately identifies and describes the Indus and Ganges river systems, mentioning their importance.
Accurately identifies and describes the Indus, Ganges, and Brahmaputra river systems, highlighting their geographical locations and significance to the civilization.
Does not describe the physical setting or its role in supporting the civilization.
Provides a vague description of the physical setting with no connection to the rise of the civilization.
Describes the physical setting but struggles to explain how it supported the civilization's rise.
Connects some aspects of the physical setting (e.g., fertile land) to the support of the civilization but lacks depth.
Clearly describes the physical setting (river valleys, climate, resources) and explains how these elements supported the rise of the civilization.

Provides a comprehensive description of the physical setting, thoroughly explaining how factors like fertile land, water availability, and geographical protection supported the rise and sustainability of the civilization, including specific examples.
Demonstrates no understanding of geographic terms or concepts.
Uses inaccurate geographic terms or demonstrates a misunderstanding of basic concepts.
Uses some geographic terms correctly but lacks consistency.
Generally uses accurate geographic terms but may have minor errors.
Uses accurate geographic terminology appropriately and consistently.
Demonstrates sophisticated understanding of geographic terms and concepts, using them precisely and effectively to enhance descriptions and explanations.
